newsitem.title: FRANCE: France calls off CIC bank privatization.
newsitem.headline: France calls off CIC bank privatization.

text.p: France called off the $1.9 billion privatisation sale of regional banking group CIC Thursday and accused the management of the bank and its state-owned parent of failing to help with the sale.
Finance Minister Jean Arthuis announced the cancellation of a sell-off tender launched in August, but said that he was determined that the bank would be sold eventually.

CIC, or Credit Industriel et Commercial, is a profitable chain of 11 regional banks whose main customers are medium and large companies and whose sell-off was seen as a prerequisite for the eventual sale of its parent, insurer GAN, to the private sector.
"After serious reflection, the government has decided to call off the privatisation process for CIC," Arthuis told a news conference.
"It seemed important that everyone had the necessary time for reflection," he said, referring to the sale of 67 percent of CIC shares with a book value of about 9.4 billion francs ($1.85 billion).
"The managers of GAN and CIC did not behave in a way to encourage progress in this process," Arthuis said.
He said he had decided to abandon the privatisation in view of public and staff reactions to the sale but that the government remained determined to sell CIC in the future.
"There is no question of not privatising CIC," he said.
